abstract.p: Thomas J Crowley letter contends that drain on power availability by high temperatures highlights vulnerability of power grid (S)

block.p: Re ''Scramble to Avoid Blackouts as Record Heat Wilts Region'' (front page, Aug. 10): The drain on power availability by high temperatures highlights the vulnerability of the power grid. This vulnerability will increase if climate model projections of greenhouse warming are correct.

Re ''Scramble to Avoid Blackouts as Record Heat Wilts Region'' (front page, Aug. 10): The drain on power availability by high temperatures highlights the vulnerability of the power grid. This vulnerability will increase if climate model projections of greenhouse warming are correct.

For the purpose of risk planning, one does not need to prove greenhouse warming, only to make a reasonable case. Sufficient climate evidence now indicates a significant likelihood of increased greenhouse summer warming, with the additional possibility of increased frequency of heat waves.

How would the power grid perform if the present heat wave were a few degrees higher (such sudden bursts are not uncommon)? This is one of the questions that planners need to address when assessing future energy needs.
THOMAS J. CROWLEY Durham, N.C., Aug. 10, 2001
The writer is a climate scientist at Duke University.
